qas.question: What is Edward Grant a historian of?
Who argued that scholars in the Middle Ages were rarely coerced by the Church?
According to Grant, the medieval use of reason was the forerunner the revolutionary rationalism of what century?

context: Others argue that reason was generally held in high regard during the Middle Ages. <a0_0>Science<a0_0/> historian Edward Grant writes, "If revolutionary rational thoughts were expressed [in the <a2_0>18th<a2_0/> century], they were only made possible because of the long medieval tradition that established the use of reason as one of the most important of human activities". Also, contrary to common belief, <a1_0>David Lindberg<a1_0/> writes, "the late medieval scholar rarely experienced the coercive power of the church and would have regarded himself as free (particularly in the natural sciences) to follow reason and observation wherever they led".
